{"step_by_step_thinking": "Ludwig's angina is a rapidly spreading cellulitis of the floor of the mouth, characterized by hardened induration of the floor and suprahyoid region bilaterally with an elevation of the tongue potentially obstructing the airway. This is mentioned in Document [1]. Trismus is a late finding in Ludwig's angina as mentioned in Document [22]. There is no mention of elevation of ear lobe or unilateral swelling in the documents.", "answer_choice": "A. Raised tongue"}
